definition:
Let $(X,d)$ be a pseudometric space. As in a metric space, we define
$$B_\varepsilon(x)=\{ y\in X\mid d(x,y)<\varepsilon \}.$$ for $x\in X$,
$\varepsilon>0$.

In the below, we show that the collection of sets
$$\mathscr{B}= \{ B_\varepsilon(x)\mid \varepsilon>0, x\in X\}$$ form a
base for a topology for $X$. We call this topology the on $X$ induced by
$d$. Also, a topological space $X$ is a *pseudometrizable topological
space* if there exists a pseudometric $d$ on $X$ whose pseudometric
topology coincides with the given topology for $X$ [@kelley; @willard].

$\mathscr{B}$ is a base for a topology.

We shall use the to prove that $\mathscr{B}$ is a base.

First, as $d(x,x)=0$ for all $x\in X$, it follows that $\mathscr{B}$ is
a cover. Second, suppose $B_1,B_2\in \mathscr{B}$ and
$z\in B_1\cap B_2$. We claim that there exists a $B_3\in \mathscr{B}$
such that $$\begin{aligned}
\label{ii} 
  z&\in& B_3\subseteq B_1\cap B_2.\end{aligned}$$ By definition,
$B_1 = B_{\varepsilon_1}(x_1)$ and $B_2 = B_{\varepsilon_2}(x_2)$ for
some $x_1,x_2\in X$ and $\varepsilon_1,\varepsilon_2>0$. Then
$$d(x_1, z)<\varepsilon_1, \quad   d(x_2, z)<\varepsilon_2.$$ Now we can
define
$\delta = \min\{ \varepsilon_1-d(x_1, z), \varepsilon_2-d(x_2, z)\}>0$,
and put $$B_3 = B_\delta(z).$$ If $y\in B_3$, then for $k=1,2$, we have
by the triangle inequality $$\begin{aligned}
d(x_k,y) &\le & d(x_k, z) + d(z,y) \\
         &< & d(x_k, z) + \delta \\
         &\le & \varepsilon_k,\end{aligned}$$ so $B_3\subseteq B_k$ and
condition \[ii\] holds.

### Remark {#remark .unnumbered}

In the proof, we have not used the fact that $d$ is symmetric.
Therefore, we have, in fact, also shown that any quasimetric induces a
topology.

[9]{} J.L. Kelley, *General Topology*, D. van Nostrand Company, Inc.,
1955. S. Willard, *General Topology*, Addison-Wesley, Publishing
Company, 1970.
